Award.AwardTitle: FMitF: Track II: Programming by Demonstration for the Browser with Applications in Data Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Future work will revolve around consuming data, deriving insights, and making data-informed decisions. While data analysis and machine learning can be significantly automated, an irreducibly human part of the data-driven future is data collection and curation. Currently, data collection is done either by experienced engineers or through manual data collection. Programming by Demonstration (PBD) has recently allowed non-experts to author automatic web-scraping programs, which collect data efficiently and reliably. This project will extend a previously developed system for browser-based PBD and evaluate it in a large-scale deployment. The scale will be large both in terms of users and the size of data that will be collected.

The system development part of the project will focus on two parts: (1) Implementing and deploying algorithms for large-scale deployment of the Helena browser-based PBD system. This work will include parallelization of synthesized web-scraper programs, making programs robust to failures of web sites and the network, and adapting the parallel execution to optimize for either the data collection rate or the cost of datacenter time. (2) Developing a next-generation user interface that will include support for debugging the synthesized programs. The target audience of these tools will be teams of data-driven social scientists with whom the PI team has had long-term collaborations. These teams have been using the Helena PBD system for collecting datasets that improve strategies of non-profits and influence government policies. The evaluation will investigate both the system performance and the usability of the novel and critical parts of the Helena ecosystem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramElement.Text: FMitF: Formal Methods in the F

POR.DRECONTENT:
The future of work will revolve around consuming data, deriving insights from the data, and making data-informed decisions.  Organizations, companies, and governments with access to richer data will make the best use of world resources, becoming more competitive. While data analysis and machine learning can be significantly automated, an irreducibly human part of the data-driven future is data collection and curation. Currently, data collection is done either by experienced engineers or through manual data collection.  The former is expensive while the latter is too inefficient and error-prone, especially when collecting large data sets. 

 

In this project, developed and deployed a programming system for data collection from web sites. The system is aimed at end users and other workers without expertise in computer science. The system is based on Programming by Demonstration (PBD): the user demonstrates in the web browser how they would collect the data manually, and the system automatically generates a program that collects the rest of the data by crawling the web site. 

 

Specifically, we extended an existing system called Helena and evaluated it in a large-scale deployment. Our target audience were teams of data-driven social scientists with whom we have had long-term collaborations.  These teams have been using our PBD system for collecting datasets that improve strategies of non-profits and influence government policies. Additionally, we collected COVID related datasets and began their integration into the NSF Open KNowledge Network that is developed in the C-Accel program. 

 

Among technical contributions of this project was improving the support for long-running Helena programs (these are programs that require hours or days to collect a web dataset, such as large-scale longitudinal scraping tasks.  This effort included several subgoals, including helping users (i) spin up and monitor hundreds of Helena instances spread over multiple machines, (ii) integrate results from clusters of Helena instances, and (iii) deciding how many scrapers and how much scraping time to devote to each task in a suite.

 

We made Helena publicly available as a Chrome extension, as well as in source code format, at github. It has been used by tens of users. It is also available in a docker format. We gave invited tutorials at the eScience Institute and users of Helena unrelated to our team began to give tutorials on Helena. The tutorial is available at https://helena-lang.org/resources. 

 


Last Modified: 04/21/2021
Modified by: Rastislav Bodik

Organizations, companies, and governments with access to richer data will make the best use of world resources, becoming more competitive. While data analysis and machine learning can be significantly automated, an irreducibly human part of the data-driven future is data collection and curation. Currently, data collection is done either by experienced engineers or through manual data collection. The former is expensive while the latter is too inefficient and error-prone, especially when collecting large data sets. In this project, developed and deployed a programming system for data collection from web sites. The system is aimed at end users and other workers without expertise in computer science. The system is based on Programming by Demonstration (PBD): the user demonstrates in the web browser how they would collect the data manually, and the system automatically generates a program that collects the rest of the data by crawling the web site. Specifically, we extended an existing system called Helena and evaluated it in a large-scale deployment. Our target audience were teams of data-driven social scientists with whom we have had long-term collaborations. These teams have been using our PBD system for collecting datasets that improve strategies of non-profits and influence government policies. Additionally, we collected COVID related datasets and began their integration into the NSF Open KNowledge Network that is developed in the C-Accel program. Among technical contributions of this project was improving the support for long-running Helena programs (these are programs that require hours or days to collect a web dataset, such as large-scale longitudinal scraping tasks. This effort included several subgoals, including helping users (i) spin up and monitor hundreds of Helena instances spread over multiple machines, (ii) integrate results from clusters of Helena instances, and (iii) deciding how many scrapers and how much scraping time to devote to each task in a suite. We made Helena publicly available as a Chrome extension, as well as in source code format, at github. It has been used by tens of users. It is also available in a docker format. We gave invited tutorials at the eScience Institute and users of Helena unrelated to our team began to give tutorials on Helena. The tutorial is available at https://helena-lang.org/resources.
